item.title: Applying Jobs to be Done to Packaging and Pricing
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
Once you understand the customer’s desired progress and what it’s worth to him to make that progress, you can start to understand the value your feature offers. This is a much better anchor of price than any sort of cost- or market-based calculation.

The post Applying Jobs to be Done to Packaging and Pricing appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Jobs to be Done: A Theory With a Mysterious Past
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
The first time I heard about Jobs to be Done it made perfect sense. It was almost TOO obvious. We don’t buy products, we buy them for what they help us do. As a product designer and innovator, I was excited about how this view of the world could help the companies I worked for, …

Continue reading "Jobs to be Done: A Theory With a Mysterious Past"

The post Jobs to be Done: A Theory With a Mysterious Past appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Nine Things to Consider Before Setting Up Your Jobs to be Done Interviews
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
Jobs to be Done interviews (JTBD interviews) are a great way to gather unique customer insights you can use to transform your business – if done correctly. The theory behind Jobs to be Done is that customers have progress they want to make in their lives. They hire products and services they believe will help …

The post Nine Things to Consider Before Setting Up Your Jobs to be Done Interviews appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Top 5 “Jobs To Be Done” Mistakes Product People Make
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
Innovators, product managers and marketers alike are embracing the Jobs to be Done mindset to design and sell products customers love. Jobs to be Done: customers have progress they want to make in their lives. They hire products and services they believe will help them get the job done (under specific circumstances). There is no …

item.title: Need Help Recruiting Beta Users for an MVP You’re Testing?
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
If you conduct any sort of customer research, chances are you’re spending too much time finding interviewees, and want to find a better way. One platform we’ve used both to recruit and to test new products ourselves is Erlibird. ErliBird gives you the power to beta test with real people in real environments and collect …

The post Need Help Recruiting Beta Users for an MVP You’re Testing? appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Focus on Customer Problems, But Don’t Lose Sight of Other Market Forces.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
Jeff Bezos has famously cautioned against being too focused on competitors. But being customer- rather than competitor-focused doesn’t mean you should ignore everything else.

The post Focus on Customer Problems, But Don’t Lose Sight of Other Market Forces. appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Your Open Innovation Program is Going to Fail. Here’s Why.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
First off, it’s not your fault. We’ve all read the articles extolling the virtues of lean start-up; empowering internal employees to experiment and bring forth new products and services. We want our employees to feel engaged, and have an outlet to share their recommendations and suggestions. How could having passionate people contribute ideas for the betterment …

The post Your Open Innovation Program is Going to Fail. Here’s Why. appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Sustaining Growth With The Three Horizons Model for Innovation
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
In 2000, Consultants from McKinsey & Company, Inc proposed a portfolio management approach known as the Three Horizons. Each horizon describes the maturity and relative risk of projects, and is a way to allow companies to manage a portfolio of projects for current and future growth. The model was first introduced in the book “The Alchemy …

The post Sustaining Growth With The Three Horizons Model for Innovation appeared first on Innovation & New Product Development | Frameplay | Ottawa, Canada | JTBD : Design Thinking : Workshops.

item.title: Investing for Your Product’s Retirement
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
Logic isn’t what drives our behavior. And it explains why so many companies aren’t investing in innovation.

item.title: Not Just for Designers: Design Thinking is Everywhere
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hill
item.description:
If Agile software development changed how we delivered value to customers, and SaaS changed how we capture value from customers, Design Thinking changes EVERYTHING.
